review_title: great opportunity for grad students... way better student jobs
job_title: Research Assistant in Rio Piedras, PR
pros:
Prestige, work environment, people are very friendly.
As the number one institution of the country, you are sure to get top notch researchers to work with. In addition, there are many fields available. As a grad student with assistanship, you get free tuition.
cons:
salaries could be higher. Pays less than a US University.
sometimes, lack of professionalism from other employees
parking is insufficient and not comfortable.
There often are strikes and you can't get to your research lab or the library. You never know what mentor you will be assigned, so, sometimes, if unlucky, you can get paired up with an unpleasant person or unprofessional professor.
as a grad assistant, you do not qualify for benefits package, and the low compensation is not enough to afford medical insurance, even university services. Overall, you need something to complement your graduate assistanship to make ends meet.

review_title: My experience as a make- up artist was amazing I have no more word to describe it.
job_title: Make Up Artist in San Juan, PR
pros: I loved all the students that didn't knew me but knew that I was there same age and the still respected me so much and so many other things too.
cons: Some of the challenge I had to face where some of me co-workers because just some of them where older than me the where abele to bossing round and this led me to make the diction to quit my job.

job_title: Social Worker I in Mayaguez, PR
pros: Work study program for students was very understanding with scheduling, and when you can go in to work. Plus, you get to work on campus, and just walk to class and back to put in those extra couple if hours.
cons: No cons that I can think of at all. I really recommend that students should always try to be part of the work-study program.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in San Juan, PR
pros: Best reasons to work here are the benefits such as: health insurance coverage, sick leave license, vacation license, retirement plan. Also, flexible hours in case of studying and special occasions, that can be arranged. Many workshops and academic activities are also available.
cons: Downsides: so many deductions from salary. For example, each paycheck almost $300 are deducted in social security, taxes, retirement, savings, and dental plan (optional). Therefore, the amount that you receive is not much compared to the gross salary. Also, the private sector pays more for the same position.

job_title: Teacher Assistant in San Juan, PR
pros: Great experience and good use of time while studying. Involvement in special projects and events not only around the classroom. Tuition exemption and stipend helps a lot. One of the things I miss the most out my time there.
cons: This is not a job for simply anyone, different than "work/study". Very different dynamics depending on the professor assigned, requires adjusting (but is part of the experience acquired). The work load is concentrated in specific times of the semester, taking a lot of time around your own due dates.

job_title: PhD Student in Mayaguez, PR
pros: The university faculty and administration always encourages you to explore different aspects of your degree. The care and support they give makes you feel at home. I definitely encourage to join as an international student.
cons: Everyone here tends to speak in Spanish rather than English. This will be difficult for some international students to have a community in the school.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in San Juan, PR
pros: Low pressure environment with lots of leeway for vacation and flexible work hours.
cons: So much bureaucratic red tape. Nearly everything is still recorded on paper and typically only one person in an office knows how to do or is willing to do the task you need to get paperwork completed. Everyone is laid back, but this means they take long lunch times and leave early often. Many rules regarding paperwork do not make any sense.

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Juan, PR
pros: Flexibility with time management, excellent medical insurance plan, best University in PR, receive the best students from the island therefore the level of teaching can go deeper.
cons:
To obtain tenure is not necessarily related to performance but for others stuffs. There is no a plan to growth in: campus size, enrollment, research and new full time faculty with tenure.
They relied mainly in contracts for professors and most of the cases are part timers.

job_title: Associate Professor in Rio Piedras, PR
pros: I was surrounded by very capable peers from whom I constantly learned. I had reasonable flexibility with my time management, which was great.
cons: Salaries are low. There is way too much bureaucracy and politics. Facilities are not always well kept. Sub par system for student registration.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Juan, PR
pros: flexible schedule, benefits, friendly work environment
cons: slow to file paperwork, very beaureaucratic admin system, poor system for bookkeeping/admin/accounts, main language is Spanish - not everyone speaks English, resistant to update admin systems for accounts, paperwork, etc.

job_title: Programner and Analyst in Bayamon, PR
pros: The group had all the equipment necessary to make the job and if not the administration was willing to help us
cons: With all the changes the administration was doing to the systems we felt confuse sometimes

job_title: Graduate Student
pros: As a graduate student, the engineering program is a great source for future opportunities. In only two years of research I met several PhD scientists, had two internships, collaborated with other departments, and even published a peer reviewed research!
cons: The experience may vary depending on the mentor, in my case I had a very productive experience.

job_title: Tenured Professor in San Juan, PR
pros: Steady pay, decent parking and localization; not bad for networking. Broad curriculum and themes, good international invitees. Some buildings are decent and the surroundings are not depressing like many places.
cons: Bureaucracy and some political bias and corruption brings it down somewhat, in some cases, it may become a very serious matter.

review_title: It has been ups and downs, but most fo all downs.  Doenst let you grow up as a professional
job_title: Financial Aid in Rio Piedras, PR
pros: well at least i got job right now, theres a big problem with the jobs in puerto rico

job_title: Student Worker in Rio Piedras, PR
pros: They are very considerate of my study schedule and flexible. They also come up with plenty of activities for the employees and are very helpful in OSEI. They are fantastic!
cons: Sometimes the higher administration takes a while to get back to you and it's hard to get the job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mayaguez, PR
pros: Gives you a lot of opportunities to grow as a student, specially if approaching an engineering career.
cons: Professors tend to be a little bit off and will not be the best educators, because their teaching strategy is based on the assumption that you already know everything about the class.

job_title: Instructor in San Juan, PR
pros: The students are excellent. They are the reason I'm still working there.
cons:
Paying too little for part-time instructors. Almost no chance to get a full-time job or tenure-track.
Almost no technology in the classroom. Some instructors even bring their own projectors.
